intro: Valeriana tocopillensis, commonly known as the Tocopilla valerian, is a flowering plant native to the Andean region of Chile. It belongs to the Caprifoliaceae family and is characterized by its erect, herbaceous stems and opposite leaves. The plant produces small, clustered flowers that are typically white or pale pink, blooming during the spring and summer seasons. Valeriana tocopillensis is adapted to grow in rocky, arid environments, showcasing a high degree of drought tolerance. Its botanical features make it an interesting subject for ecological and horticultural studies in semi-desert regions.
